title: Stowe Pinnacle: Vermont's Best Short Summit Hike
author: SummitSeeker Team
excerpt: A 2,740-foot summit with 360-degree views for just 2.8 miles of hiking—Stowe Pinnacle delivers maximum Vermont scenery for minimum effort.

seo.meta_description: Stowe Pinnacle hiking guide with trail info, best times, and tips. Experience stunning Vermont views on this popular short summit hike near Stowe.

content.introduction:
If you only have time for one hike in Stowe, make it the Pinnacle. This 2,740-foot summit just east of the famous resort town packs panoramic views of Mount Mansfield, Camel's Hump, and the surrounding Green Mountains into a moderate 2.8-mile round trip. It's the kind of hike that converts casual walkers into lifelong hikers.

The trail is steep in places and rocky throughout—this is Vermont, after all—but the payoff is substantial. Standing on the bare summit with mountains in every direction, you'll understand why people fall in love with this state.

sections.heading: The Trail
sections.content:
Basic Stats

  • Distance: 2.8 miles round trip
  • Elevation Gain: 1,520 feet
  • Difficulty: Moderate
  • Time: 2-3 hours

The trail starts gently but soon begins climbing in earnest. You'll ascend through mixed hardwood forest before entering the spruce-fir zone near the top. The final section crosses open ledges with increasingly impressive views.

Watch for wet roots and rocks—the trail stays damp in places. Trekking poles help, especially on the descent.

sections.heading: The Summit
sections.content:
Stowe Pinnacle's summit is open rock with room for many hikers, though it gets crowded on nice weekends. The views include:

  • West: Mount Mansfield, Vermont's highest peak, dominates the skyline
  • Southwest: Camel's Hump's distinctive profile
  • North: Worcester Range stretching toward Canada
  • East: The hills rolling toward New Hampshire

On exceptionally clear days, you can see the White Mountains of New Hampshire to the east. Bring a map or identification app—you'll want to name all the peaks.

sections.heading: When to Hike
sections.content:
• Late May through October: Best conditions; expect crowds on weekends
  • Fall foliage (late September-early October): Spectacular colors but very busy
  • Winter: Possible with microspikes; beautiful snow-covered views
  • Mud season (April-May): Trail can be extremely muddy; consider waiting

Timing Tips

  • Start early to beat the crowds (before 8 AM on weekends)
  • Weekday mornings are relatively quiet
  • Sunset hikes are popular—bring a headlamp for the descent

sections.heading: Practical Information
sections.content:
Getting There

The trailhead is on Upper Hollow Road in Stowe, about 2 miles from the village center. Parking is limited to a small lot—arrive early on nice days or you'll be turned away.

Alternative Access

The Pinnacle Meadow Trail approaches from the south, adding distance but avoiding the parking crunch. It's 4.0 miles round trip via this route.

What to Bring

  • Sturdy footwear (rocks and roots throughout)
  • Water (no sources on trail)
  • Layers (summit can be windy)
  • Camera—the views demand documentation

Dogs

Dogs are allowed on leash. The rocky terrain can be hard on paws, so assess your dog's abilities.

Stowe Pinnacle is Vermont hiking at its finest—challenging enough to feel like an accomplishment, short enough for an afternoon, and spectacular enough to justify traveling here from anywhere. The views of Mansfield and Camel's Hump alone make it one of the most scenic short hikes in the state.
